articles.headline: For Obama, a Taste of What a Long Battle Would Hold
articles.snippet: The last few days have offered a glimpse of the Republican playbook as the party adapts to the prospect that it will be running against Senator Barack Obama.
articles.abstract: The last few days have offered a glimpse of the Republican playbook as the party adapts to the prospect that it will be running against Senator Barack Obama.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  When Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton goes after Senator Barack Obama these days, she presses him on the details of his health care plan, criticizes the wording of his campaign mailings and likens his promise of change to celestial choirs.

articles.headline: Facing Default, Some Walk Out on New Homes
articles.snippet: The same sorts of loans that drove the housing boom are now giving borrowers incentives to walk away.
articles.abstract: The same sorts of loans that drove the housing boom are now giving borrowers incentives to walk away.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Raymond Zulueta went into default on his mortgage last year, he did what a lot of people do. He worried.

articles.headline: Bipartisan Spirit Falters in Fights on Debt Relief
articles.snippet: President Bush and Democratic leaders went to war on Thursday over how to prevent widening damage from the housing crisis.
articles.abstract: President Bush and Democratic leaders went to war on Thursday over how to prevent widening damage from the housing crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Just a month after President Bush and Democratic leaders hailed their bipartisan agreement on an economic stimulus plan, the two sides went to war on Thursday over how to prevent widening damage from the housing crisis.

articles.headline: Hoping to Make Phone Buyers Flip
articles.snippet: Industry analysts say it has become more important than ever to understand the psyche of consumers.
articles.abstract: Industry analysts say it has become more important than ever to understand the psyche of consumers.
articles.lead_paragraph: These days, designing a new mobile phone can seem like something out of an episode of “Dr. Phil.”

articles.headline: Why Surprises Still Lurk After Enron
articles.snippet: After the post-Enron reforms passed by Congress, why are banks still reporting huge losses from risks not mentioned in their financial statements?
articles.abstract: After the post-Enron reforms passed by Congress, why are banks still reporting huge losses from risks not mentioned in their financial statements?

articles.headline: U.S. Embrace of Musharraf Irks Pakistanis
articles.snippet: The Bush administration’s continued backing of the Pakistani president is perceived as American meddling.
articles.abstract: The Bush administration’s continued backing of the Pakistani president is perceived as American meddling.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The Bush administration’s continued backing of President Pervez Musharraf, despite the overwhelming rejection of his party by voters this month, is fueling a new level of frustration in Pakistan with the United States.

articles.headline: Trader Accused of Betting Money He Didn’t Have
articles.snippet: For nearly two decades Evan Dooley quietly made a living trading commodities like wheat in his home state, Tennessee, far from the hurly-burly of Wall Street.
articles.abstract: For nearly two decades Evan Dooley quietly made a living trading commodities like wheat in his home state, Tennessee, far from the hurly-burly of Wall Street.
articles.lead_paragraph: For nearly two decades Evan Dooley quietly made a living trading commodities like wheat in his home state, Tennessee, far from the hurly-burly of Wall Street.

articles.headline: Sprint Nextel Posts $29.5 Billion Loss
articles.snippet: The company also said it was suspending the payment of its dividend and had borrowed $2.5 billion through a revolving credit facility.
articles.abstract: The company also said it was suspending the payment of its dividend and had borrowed $2.5 billion through a revolving credit facility.
articles.lead_paragraph: Daniel R. Hesse, Sprint Nextel’s new chief executive, tells it like it is  but on Thursday, investors did not like what they heard.

articles.headline: Kenya Rivals Reach Peace Agreement
articles.snippet: The agreement to end a political standoff creates a powerful prime minister position for the top opposition leader.
articles.abstract: The agreement to end a political standoff creates a powerful prime minister position for the top opposition leader.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya  Kenya’s rival leaders broke their tense standoff on Thursday, agreeing to share power in a deal that may end the violence that has engulfed this nation but could be the beginning of a long and difficult political relationship.

articles.headline: Blood Thinner Might Be Tied to More Deaths
articles.snippet: The F.D.A. said the number of deaths possibly associated to tainted Chinese supplies of heparin, a blood-thinning drug, had risen to 21.
articles.abstract: The F.D.A. said the number of deaths possibly associated to tainted Chinese supplies of heparin, a blood-thinning drug, had risen to 21.
articles.lead_paragraph: Amid indications that more people may have died or been harmed after being given a brand of the blood thinner heparin, federal drug regulators said Thursday that they had found “potential deficiencies” at a Chinese plant that supplied much of the active ingredient for the drug.
